Text: Okta Lost Over 8B Due To Security Scandals In Three Years Can It Ever Be Okay Again?
deleted

I cant claim to have a deep understanding of this company, but I dont see much of a future here for investors. The company has been around for about 10 years now and has never been profitable on a GAAP basis. It looks like they spend a ton on sales and have exploded headcount since 2021, which seems insane. They have around 6,000 employees now. They do have free cash flow, but thats only because of SBC, which is basically just borrowing from existing shareholders. Naturally, the balance sheet shows the share count going up every single year. But really, the obvious flag for me is that Okta just does the one thing, and while that one thing is pretty darn important, it just doesnt seem investable to me. And then in addition to that, I question the management decision to hire so many people. I mean, how can a company that is this specialized have so many employees? What are all these people doing? It really doesnt make sense.
Theyll be fine long term this isnt nearly as big of an issue as something like what happened with CRWD

Its shameful how little I know about the OKTA scandals but the breach I know of and see stated here is the customer ticket breach which shouldnt contain any end customer data unless as part of the ticket OKTA consumers sent files with the information. The super users being able to access end customer data from their home pc is still true. But this is a bit of a shared responsibility as the enterprises must be aware who they give super admin access to. That aside the new oAuth page has very promising innovative features enabling enterprises to utilize more authentication means using the same solution they already pay for.
Probably market cap but Im also curious
I have no idea! And on top of that, they have some many ppl and still had some issues, so..

Its trying really hard to be in PAM and IGA! Also the may have a sales and employee churn issue aside from the fact that they are likely doing another employee cut to stay lean at end of fiscal. Current customer spend might be up but their last sales teams built really bad deals coming up for renewal this year and next while the economy tightens and the new sales team cant close enough business...awful recipe
Where did you get this information from lol? Couldnt be any more wrong.
but that wasnt an issue, that was a nightmare!
Exactly, I was talking about market cap and how much they lost when these security issues happened

I dont think OKTA stock drop had much to do with those breaches as they were not a substantial risk to their business. A number of companies have had hacks including multiple hacks at Microsoft but scope is very limited. Software and SaaS stocks have dropped quite a bit over the past 2 years well off their highs. OKTA in the same boat as SNOW ZM PAYC MDB TEAM to name a few slower revenue growth. CRM has held up, WDAY maybe up a little, and NOW is an outlier.
My first attempt at due diligence Klaviyo KVYO

What are the risks? Whats the bear case? Back in the day, due diligence was mostly about figuring out what could make a company fail, not just hyping up stuff from their press releases and financial reports. Maybe dig deeper into the rest of the space, the competition, and what their market share is and what theyre doing to increase that. This company doesnt exist in isolation.

Business model is trash. The best place for ads is in Video YouTube, TikTok, on TV, in cinemas, where you can not ignore them. No one wants spam email or spam SMS. Also there is no moat, sending emails is old tech.

I had a look at their 2023 10k and latest 10q. Their marketing expenses are big and increasing any time they record increased revenue, rd expenses even more so. They seem barely profitable if even. Their product, based on their presentation, seems solid, and they are already using llms and maybe image generators in their services, which makes sense in their market segment. Can they stay profitable sustainably if they lower marketing and rd spend growth or would they have cutthroat competition and would lose customers if they did so? On the other note, good on them for giving long time employees 1 month sabbatical.
Since this post it went from about 30 to 40, and currently around 34 after an earnings drop. All the comments are basically trashing the company lol, always inverse reddit

Isnt AI a very big risk for this company ? I could be wrong but it seems that it only takes an investment from one of the big players in telecom space to use chat GPT to automate SMS sending, and this company will be irrelevant.

I dont recognize all of them, but I do have stock in some of them like TTD and the business has done very well, growing revenue and such. And becoming a leader in their DSP space in Connected TV. Microsoft and Amazon are strong businesses as well.

I expect at some point SP will have to drop the bad performers and take on new companies and this will trigger big price changes. I dont think one can time the dropping companies, but you can stay with the well performing ones without needing liquidity.

They are delivering good numbers top line, bottom line, all good, cash flow OK and the next year should be a good year for them with more coverage coming their way. Their problem is stock dilution. They issued 280M worth of stock in May and expect 50M more by the end of FY. Thats way too much for a company of their size and thats why their stock price is where it is. If they can ditch the dilution for consistent operating cash flow next year, they could double in price.
Companies get addeddropped quite frequently, this is part of the reason the SP500 index is so powerful.
The quarterly index rebalance is a feature of mostall major indices.

This could be used as a test of the OPs thesis that being included in the index props up a companys value. Once SPY or VOO reflect the rebalance, the price should shoot up for a company thats been added, or drop for a company thats been removed.
Three Data Breaches in Three Years Why Do We Still Have Okta?
User Report Total Submissions 1 First Seen In WSB just now Total Comments 0 Previous Best DD Account Age 3 years Join WSB Discord

Its because corporate security checklists have become so onerous that the only solution is flawed products like this. The idea that companies can and should outsource one of their most critical functions, in a way that is really hard to insource later should never have gotten traction in the first place. With the amount of money just one fortune 500 company spends on this, it could fund a proper open source project to implement something that could be run securely in house, and then youd have fewer big central targets holding billions of records out there.
Migrating all of these apps to Okta took years. Migrating them off of Okta will also take years. Thats the story where I work.
So buy calls? Got it coach.

Its like putting a Masterlock on your high school locker it keeps out 99 of malicious hackers, and the 1 hack event every year that does make it through would have compromised just about any inhouse solution. Plus inhouse solutions are expensive and vulnerable to zeroday attacks every day.
they hire dumbfucks. thats why they suck.
Im pretty sure everyones data has been leaked now.
Because when the only punishment is fines, its just legal for a price and then if news doesnt report on it no one will know or care in 3 months

Sounds like these hackers are getting what they need out of it, then selling the access to another group. I know Lapus did this a couple years ago with the twillio, okta, door dash and some other companies. If three data breaches have occurred within the past few years alone. That means okta is not hardening their systems and the same vulnerabilities are exposed. Or there is a backdoor that they havent found and theirs different groups that are still within their system. Hackers might wait months or years before making a move. It can also take months for an enterprise to realize theyve been breached. They need to fully remediate their systems, harden them, and implement better endpoint detection. They also need to monitor the traffic on known and of course unknown services running during business hours. They also need to implement better access control user policies. Along with more social engineer training. Alot of their workers still might be working from home, meaning more social engineering tactics can be used. This also means they are running their computers on their own home networks

Your info is actually just incorrect. Lapsus gained access to a support engineers computer, but the most power they had was to reset passwords and MFA factors. They were unable to obtain passwords, create or delete users, or download customer databases. Approx 2.5 of Okta customers were affected. In 2022, GitHub notified Okta that software repositories hosted in GitHub was copied. Not an Okta breach. In 2023, an attacker had unauthorized access to files inside Oktas customer support system. While true that data was leaked, this was limited to names and email addresses within the support systems. No user credentials or sensitive data was accessed. Oktas production systems were untouched. To this point, Oktas production systems have not been breached. After the most recent event in 2023 they pushed everything on their product roadmap for a security hardening. Their technology remains the best on the market by a long shot and gives folks the best chance at keeping their environments secure. Given the focus back on innovation after the security hardening as well as the huge reductions in price on the auth0 platform and expansion free licensing, I expect them to gain significant market share as they weed out low cost competitors and open source options

Stockholm syndrome, entrenchment, and lack of adversary. Also with gaureenteed government backstop no error is ever dooming. Look at crowdstrike. They crippled the world for 2 months. And since theres no adversity, no rush to get things moving again, thus no real damage. Theres no black and white to it, just gradual fade and stagnation

Very simple answer Its guaranteed lots of work now to switch off Okta, and bosses blame IT for the hassle, downtime and cost. Its potentially lots of work later to deal with an Okta breach, and any downtime or cost gets blamed on Okta not IT.
The same reason u have managers telling u working in office is better
Who maintains it? Once big corp creates it and their competitors start using it, what incentive is there.
Theres not a ton of good options to migrate to, it also a zero improvement migration which are always very difficult to sell up the chain.

The other vendors may be better on a technical level but tend to be absolute shit at the business side which means those in charge of paying them are pissed off their jobs get tougher for using the nerdapproved vendor, which puts pressure on execs. Hell, Okta bought Auth0 so there goes one other nonOkta option. Keycloak is open source with no vendor thatll do the enterprisereadiness work so its basically dead in the water for most organizations even if its a much cheaper to run product solution because after the implementation someone needs to be around for executives and legal! to choke if somethings wrong. Being able to blame stuff other than your own incompetence is pretty key to corporate decision processes, lets be honest.
You are using a MasterLock model 69, it can be opened with a MasterLock model 69

No, its like stringing a cable through every locker in the school, and then getting surprised that someone bothered clipping it and robbing everyone at once, when they would have had to clip a thousand separate master locks if they went in house.
More than likely valid credentials from phishing or data dump
Didnt get the job huh ?
News did report on it and nobody still cares

Ive had success with calls on KVYO! And have put part of the profits into shares. Nice DD!

As a marketing director who has managed the budgets and brands of 10 millions dollar brands... who also switched from MailChimp to Kalviyo at times... its not the revolution in email marketing it seems like youre positioning it to be. Itll be a slow, minimally incremental climb over time at best. Theyre just as, If not more expensive than MailChimp for one. The only factor in my switching from MC is purely some added automation features. But again, I still ended up paying WAY more than MailChimp. Businesses like the ones I managed who had 500K 1m annual marketing budgets only see an incremental difference in effectiveness at an astronomical cost. Klaviyo does benefit the little guys moreif you have a low subscriber count and just need the basics, fine. But these same smaller guys are pissing away like a min 200500month IF THAT ad spend on metagooglewtv ads because its all they can afford. Meanwhile again, the real money is being spent by the big brands with larger budgets... and these big brands are better served by a service like salesforce because it solves the actual problems services like klaviyo or MC claim to solve, but theres a huge learning curve and restructuring in building these data analytics in even these large companies right now.. but in my experience, theyre starting to wise up to where the real problems are and where a real solution may lay. Klaviyos customer base of amateur shopify dropshippers with little to no funds are likely 75 of their end users, and if thats not true it will be eventually as like I said, big businesses start to wisen up as to how to do better data consolidation. Also, klaviyos sales teams are the single most grating, frustrating and annoying experience Ive endured and working in marketing, thats fucking impressive.
You promised me monies
Nothing I can do about waiting for cash to settle. But also the purpose was just to provide some DD. Not tryna convince anyone to take positions thats for them to decide.
I agree that could be a cause for concern. However, with the new integrations they have and the expansion deals stated above, I do believe that could help mitigate their reliance on Shopify.

Thanks for the input, I did see that It was more expensive than MC I should have included that inside the post. What do you think Salesforce does better than KVYO specifically if you dont mind me asking? Are the high prices not worth it in the eyes of bigger companies like those aforementioned?
Could you expand on the sales team piece? Their sales recruiter reached out to me

KVYO is starting to move into enterprise as indicated by a few recent earnings calls. Generally speaking, Salesforce is an absolute nightmare for ecommerce brands as it wasnt built for that. KVYO offers a builtin CDP and a robust databaseanalytics suite if a brand can use it effectively and a big perk to KVYO is that it is relatively easy to use, its super powerful. Mailchimp doesnt offer that depth for personalization, automation, etc and may be stuck serving SMB forever. If KVYO continues to move into enterprise and can serve the same needs that BrazeSalesforceBloomreach does, theres massive upside..

It depends on the nature of those new integrations. Their product is basically when something happens in Shopify, do something in another system. So if theyre just increasing the number of integrations with other systems its nothing different. The toast integration is interesting
MC was built for SMB and will likely stay that way for the future as thats the cohort they serve best. Comparing pricing between MC and KVYO feels pointless. You get what you pay for.

What do you think about MailChimp slacking and losing over 20,000 brands to Klaviyo? That was their main competitor. Sure it can come across pretty simplistic with Shopify does X so we do Y, but I do feel its a little more nuanced than that. They send data centric or personalized messages based on the data from said customer, which I do thinks helps their efficiency.

I wasnt trying to be overly reductive about their product, simply trying to say that the nature of their product relies heavily on the usage of a base ecommerce platform like Shopify or bigcommerce. Thats why toast is interesting, because its another heavily used base ecommerce product tho, a bit different as its point of sale, and that opens up a large untapped TAM for them. That alone is the bullish thesis for me.
removed

I agree I do think the integration with Toast is pretty good news, but apart from their partnership with Shopify, what other cons are there that I may be overlooking? Theres not a whole lot of precedent since they only IPOed last September.

Klaviyo has very specific requirements about capturing user consent before any engagement with the user can happen. Things like mail chimp dont, which make them more extensible to a myriad of use cases including b2b saas. Thats why we didnt go with them after we demod.

Too much talk earlier this year about a potential buyout. Multiple banks and private equity funds kept throwing around a 13B valuation. I think itll be tough for the market to push docusign above that psychological valuation anytime soon.

Dont actively follow DocuSign, but looking at the fundamentals, the Price to Free Cashflow PFCF 3 years ago was over 100 on a trailing 12 month basis. Revenue Growth was over 30 year on year, which I expect was partly due to high uptake in COVID. Expect this high year on year revenue growth was driving the high PFCF and with growth dropping over the last 3 years has lead to the large drop in share price. Right now the PFCF is sitting around 12, which I think is cheap if they can keep growing revenue and FCF. If they can keep up the growth, Id expect the share price to increase. Whether it can get back to 250 in the next 5 years will depend on whether they can accelerate their growth and whether you want to wait a bit for it to get to that level.

Im of the personal opinion that the reason why prices have been plummeting post earnings, beating, smashing, or missing, is due to a massive influx of options traders who have no clue what theyre doing. They read about upcoming earnings, they hear you can get mega rich off options, they read up on some of the companies and then just yolo hundreds or thousands into short term calls. When earnings arrive they then get completely blasted by Theta Burn which in turn will drive the stock price down which will then blow up IV Crush, both feed into itself and ultimately makes the stock price plummet. This has happened with Celsius, Reddit, Hims, you name it. Its only the under the radar stocks that have earnings go well where you see a legitimate climb, like Git Lab most recently.

Its a decent point about the valuation. With that kind of revenue growth, investors might expect more if theyre paying a premium. Seems like theres a lot of speculation and not much faith in those fundamentals. Sometimes, the hype just doesnt line up with reality, and these stocks take a while to find their footing again. Feels like were stuck in a waiting game here.

Wow.  one can't say much without offending the yahoo review board.  So I have a couple responses to the below comments.  First, look at the cash flow statement and you will see that stock based compensation is EXTREMELY high relative to the operating income generated by this company.  Yes, every company has stock based compensation but not this high.  Revenue, in my opinion, is not growing nearly fast enough to offset.  Second, this compensation is not broad based compensation to all employees but only a select few.  Lastly, this is likely driving the poor morale at the company as leadership tries to gain productivity at the expense of its lower levels to justify the huge compensation.  Stated in other words, this stock price has gotten ahead of it's ability to compensate it's own employees.  Doesn't look pretty from here.

OMG.  I was thinking about putting some money into this stock until I saw the stock based compensation.  LOL.  This would be a REALLY successful company but for the fact they are passing all the profits to their employees.  You've basically invested in an employee owned company.  Good luck.
